body: That certainly does look like a bug in GLFW.
I can confirm this happens to me as well, I have also tested a wired PS3 controller, while I can output their names the snippet of code above does indeed print that same result.
This became broken in 58ae11778aa7ce50d07ec0acae14f41a24733595  "Replaced expensive IOKit function."
I've just tested this as well and I get the same result as @tgoulart - all 0's

I have also encountered this issue.  GLFW (3.0.2) detects the joystick (a Logitech Extreme 3D), but does not identify its axes or buttons.  I've done some digging and the problem arises because the code in _glfwInitJoysticks (cocoa_joystick.m) for enumerating the HID elements of the joystick only gets a single array element (representing the "root" of the device).  That element is an "Application Collection" (kIOHIDElementCollectionTypeApplication), which is represented by a dictionary.  The function addJoystickElement expects it to have an kIOHIDElementKey field (which would be the children elements), but it does not, so the axis and button elements are not detected.

I don't know if this situation is because of a bug in Apple's code for enumerating the elements of the device or in GLFW's query.  I did notice that Apple's sample code (e.g., HID_Dumper) uses a different set of library function from IOHIDLib.h for enumerating HID devices and elements of those devices.

The problem is that repeatedly using `IORegistryEntryCreateCFProperties` cased significant slowdown of `glfwInit` with some gamepads (on the order of seconds, iirc), which is why the switch was made to `IORegistryEntryCreateCFProperty`. I'll look into this further once 3.0.3 (which is solely focused on cursor input on OS X) is out.
Would it make sense to switch to using the HID API instead of using th IO registry API (which Apple's docs describe as the legacy API)?
@JohnReppy I don't yet know enough about the details to say, but considering Apple's history with APIs, likely yes.
Verified on 10.8.5 using a 360 controller clone.

I have been hacking around, and seem to have got my PS3 controller working using the new HID API.
Still cleaning up some loose ends, but should have a patch available soon.
BTW  - the osx code still inverts the y axis - I take it that code should be removed now (per issue #146 )?
@proc-addr Great news. Yes, remove all axis inversion.

issue.body:
This function used to enumerate all devices and capture all properties
of every device into a dictionary. This takes 180 ms on a MacBook Pro
without external devices and 280 ms with an external keyboard/mouse
attached.

Since we're only interested in a few properties, we can just get them
one by one - this reduces the time to <1 ms.

issue.title: getJoystickButtons and getJoystickAxes are returning Nothing while joystick is present.
issue.body:
It seems that I cannot get any joystick input other than name while my controller is present. 

``` haskell
    printJoystick :: Joystick -> IO ()
    printJoystick js = do
        present  <- joystickPresent js
        mname    <- getJoystickName js
        mbuttons <- getJoystickButtons js
        maxes    <- getJoystickAxes js
        print $ "Joystick: " ++ show js
        print (present,mname,mbuttons,maxes)

    -- "Joystick: Joystick'1"
    -- (True,Just "Logitech Dual Action",Nothing,Nothing)
```

Perhaps this is not a glfw-b issue but is instead my fault for not using glfw correctly but after looking at glfw's documentation I can't find any obvious problem with the code above.

issue.title: getJoystickName returns (Just "") when joystick is not present.
issue.body:
It seems that glfw-b is returning a name regardless of whether or not a joystick is connected (and if not that name is ), which is odd because the type is IO (Maybe String):

``` haskell
    getAllJoystickNames :: IO (M.Map Joystick String)
    getAllJoystickNames = do
        let joysticks = [Joystick'1 .. Joystick'16]
        mNames <- forM joysticks $ \js -> ((js,) <$>) <$> getJoystickName js
        return $ M.fromList $ catMaybes mNames

    -- With one controller plugged in this returns:
    -- fromList [(Joystick'1,"Logitech Dual Action"),(Joystick'2,""),(Joystick'3,""),(Joystick'4,""),(Joystick'5,""),(Joystick'6,""),(Joystick'7,""),(Joystick'8,""),(Joystick'9,""),(Joystick'10,""),(Joystick'11,""),(Joystick'12,""),(Joystick'13,""),(Joystick'14,""),(Joystick'15,""),(Joystick'16,"")

    -- It seems it should return instead:
    -- fromList [(Joystick'1, "Logitech Dual Action")]
```
